sprint_retro_templates.template: This sprint executed exactly as planned. All {tickets_shipped} committed tickets shipped with the scope we promised, and the team maintained sustainable velocity throughout. There is nothing here that requires remediation or explanation, which is either a sign of excellent planning or a sign that we didn't commit to enough. We'll calibrate scope for next sprint accordingly.

Every single ticket shipped. {best_ticket_title} was {best_ticket_outcome_summary}, setting a tone for the entire sprint. We hit all story points, maintained code quality gates, and nobody had to sacrifice sleep or standards. This is what sustainable delivery looks like on paper. The question now is whether we're being too conservative with our commitments or if we've finally figured out estimation.

Sprint 1 complete. {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} tickets shipped. {best_ticket_title} — {best_ticket_outcome_summary}. You're finding your rhythm, and stakeholders are starting to notice your work. Your responsibility will increase each sprint as the team learns to trust your judgment.

Sprint 1 in the books. {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} delivered, though not all landed perfectly. {best_ticket_title} — {best_ticket_outcome_summary}. Early missteps are expected; what matters is building credibility sprint by sprint as responsibility increases.

Sprint 2 done. {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} shipped successfully. {best_ticket_title} — {best_ticket_outcome_summary}. The team is learning to work with you, and your scope is expanding. Stakeholders are watching more closely now.

Sprint 2 wrapped with mixed results. {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} made it out the door. {best_ticket_title} — {best_ticket_outcome_summary}. As your responsibility grows, so does the scrutiny. The next sprint will test whether you're ready for more.

{tickets_shipped} out of {tickets_committed} tickets shipped—a strong showing overall. {best_ticket_title} performed exceptionally with {best_ticket_outcome_summary}. The few items that slipped were reasonable scope adjustments, not execution failures. We're in good position to wrap these up next sprint without any backlog accrual. Team morale is solid, and the codebase is where we want it to be.

Most items made it across the finish line this sprint, with {tickets_shipped} out of {tickets_committed} completing as designed. {best_ticket_title} was our standout—{best_ticket_outcome_summary}. The remaining tickets are well-understood and not blocking anything critical. We achieved our velocity targets without burnout, which management will frame as a sign that we can take on more work next quarter.

Delivery: {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed}. The wins outweighed the misses by a comfortable margin, with {best_ticket_title} delivering {best_ticket_outcome_summary}. Quality was maintained throughout. The few stragglers have clear owners and timelines. If this trend continues, we'll be ahead of annual targets by Q3, assuming no major incidents derail us.

This sprint was best characterized as inconsistent. {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} shipped, which is respectable but not ideal. {best_ticket_title} was a clear win—{best_ticket_outcome_summary}—but {worst_ticket_title} underperformed because {worst_ticket_outcome_summary}. The gap between our best and worst work suggests either uneven skill distribution or unreliable estimation. We need to examine what made the winners work and replicate that pattern.

{tickets_shipped} shipped, {tickets_committed} committed. The results were scattered—some tickets sailed through, others ran into expected technical challenges, and a few exposed gaps in planning. {best_ticket_title} showed what good looks like with {best_ticket_outcome_summary}. Meanwhile, {worst_ticket_title} became {worst_ticket_outcome_summary}. We have clear action items, but execution velocity was mediocre.

A tale of two sprints happened simultaneously. {best_ticket_title} landed beautifully—{best_ticket_outcome_summary}—proving our team can execute at a high level when conditions align. But {worst_ticket_title} dragged us down with {worst_ticket_outcome_summary}. Overall delivery: {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed}. The inconsistency is the real issue here, not the absolute numbers.

{tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} arrived at completion. {best_ticket_title} was {best_ticket_outcome_summary}, suggesting our team has the capability we need. {worst_ticket_title}, however, was {worst_ticket_outcome_summary}, which raises questions about either our estimation framework or our dependency management. Neither extreme was acceptable, but both offer diagnostic value. We need to understand why outcomes diverged so sharply.

This sprint was a reset. {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} made it to done—well below target. {worst_ticket_title} was {worst_ticket_outcome_summary}, and unfortunately it wasn't alone. The team faced cascading blockers, scope wasn't as well understood as we thought it was, and velocity suffered accordingly. We have a decision to make: either our planning process is broken, or our capacity assessment is wrong. Probably both.

We underdelivered. {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} shipped. Multiple tickets collided with dependencies we didn't anticipate, the codebase revealed hidden complexity, and we ended the sprint with more questions than answers. {worst_ticket_title} became a particularly revealing failure—{worst_ticket_outcome_summary}. This is the kind of sprint where we learn more from what went wrong than what went right. Unfortunately, learning is expensive.

Delivery numbers: {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed}. This sprint exposed gaps in our technical planning, communication breakdowns, and at least one significant estimation miss with {worst_ticket_title}—{worst_ticket_outcome_summary}. The team wasn't demoralized, but they were frustrated. The good news is that nothing catastrophic happened. The bad news is that this is our new baseline until we fix the fundamentals.

{tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} shipped, but that metric is almost irrelevant given what happened with {worst_ticket_title}. {worst_ticket_outcome_summary}—a failure that cascaded into customer impact and required unplanned remediation hours. {best_ticket_title} being {best_ticket_outcome_summary} is cold comfort. The sprint is defined by the disaster, not the deliverables. We need a comprehensive incident review and corrective action plan before moving forward.

We had an incident. {worst_ticket_title} resulted in {worst_ticket_outcome_summary}, which consumed the second half of this sprint and overshadowed everything else. {tickets_shipped} tickets shipped, but the quality of delivery is less important than understanding what broke. The team handled the crisis response professionally. Now we need to ensure it doesn't happen again. This changes sprint planning for the next cycle.

This sprint will be remembered for {worst_ticket_title}—{worst_ticket_outcome_summary}. The incident demanded immediate response, rework, and process changes. {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} made it through, but throughput is meaningless when there's a 5-alarm fire. The good news: the team responded quickly. The bad news: we need to prevent this kind of failure. Everything else is secondary.

We committed to too much—{overbook_pct}% above our typical capacity—and yet {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} still made it across the line. {best_ticket_title} was {best_ticket_outcome_summary}, setting the tone for scrappy execution everywhere. The team overachieved through a combination of skill and luck. This sprint proves that we can do more, which means executives will immediately ask us to do more next quarter. Sustainable velocity is now our enemy.

Despite being {overbook_pct}% overburdened, we shipped {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} items. {best_ticket_title} performed well—{best_ticket_outcome_summary}—and most other work followed suit. This sprint will be cited as evidence that the team has excess capacity. It will not be remembered for the team members who skipped lunch or worked evenings to make it happen. Expect another aggressive commitment next sprint.

We overcommitted by {overbook_pct}% and the results were predictable: {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} shipped, quality suffered, and the team ended the sprint exhausted. {worst_ticket_title} was {worst_ticket_outcome_summary}, a failure we can directly trace to insufficient time allocation. {best_ticket_title} managed to be {best_ticket_outcome_summary}, but that's the exception. Next sprint, we need realistic commitments or we'll see burnout, not heroics.

The {overbook_pct}% overbooking created exactly the problems we warned about: {tickets_shipped} shipped instead of our target, {worst_ticket_title} became {worst_ticket_outcome_summary}, and team morale took a hit. {best_ticket_title} was {best_ticket_outcome_summary}, but one win doesn't redeem an unsustainable sprint. This is the moment to have a hard conversation about capacity versus demand.

We overbooked by {overbook_pct}% and underdelivered significantly: {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} completed. {worst_ticket_title} collapsed under the pressure—{worst_ticket_outcome_summary}. The team did everything they could, but the sprint plan was fundamentally unrealistic. We've now proven that aggressive commitments don't increase output; they just increase failure. Next sprint, we commit to what we can actually deliver.

A quiet sprint is often underestimated. We shipped {tickets_shipped} tickets without drama, incident, or heroics. {best_ticket_title} was {best_ticket_outcome_summary}. Nobody stayed late, the code review process worked as intended, and dependencies were minimal. There's no story here, which is exactly the point. This is the baseline for healthy team operation. When this becomes boring enough, we'll know we've built something sustainable.

{tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} shipped in what might be our most uneventful sprint on record. No incidents, no surprises, minimal scope creep. {best_ticket_title} delivered {best_ticket_outcome_summary} on schedule. Nothing remarkable, which is remarkable in itself. The team maintained their standard pace without friction. Stakeholders will barely notice this sprint happened, which means we did our job correctly.

This sprint was explicitly designed to recover from last quarter's shortfall. We reduced scope commitment to focus on quality and morale, resulting in {tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} shipped—down in volume but up in reliability. {best_ticket_title} was {best_ticket_outcome_summary}. The team's confidence is rebuilding. We're not back to normal yet, but we're moving in the right direction.

Intentional reset sprint. After the previous quarter's difficulties, we deliberately scaled back to {tickets_shipped} items to rebuild execution credibility and team morale. {best_ticket_title} was {best_ticket_outcome_summary}, setting the tone for reliability. Quality gates are tighter. Dependencies are managed. We're climbing back to sustainable velocity. Expect gradual commitment increases as confidence returns.

{tickets_shipped} of {tickets_committed} shipped as planned—a small number intentionally chosen to rebuild team confidence after recent setbacks. {best_ticket_title} delivering {best_ticket_outcome_summary} proved that we can execute at high quality again. The previous quarter is behind us. This sprint is the foundation for a return to normal operations.

metric_warnings.tech_debt_rising: Technical debt metrics are trending upward, suggesting we're accumulating shortcuts faster than we're paying them down.
metric_warnings.tech_debt_critical: Technical debt has reached critical levels. We cannot sustain feature velocity without addressing core infrastructure issues.
metric_warnings.team_morale_dropping: Team sentiment surveys show declining morale, likely driven by sprint intensity and scope misalignment.
metric_warnings.team_morale_crisis: Team morale is in crisis territory. Retention risk is real. We need immediate action on workload and workplace culture.
metric_warnings.self_serve_stagnant: Self-serve metrics are flat or declining, which will pressure the sales team and long-term GTM strategy.
metric_warnings.enterprise_stagnant: Enterprise adoption has plateaued, reducing long-term revenue predictability and growth runway.
metric_warnings.sales_unhappy: Sales leadership has expressed frustration with feature delivery and competitive gaps.
metric_warnings.sales_furious: Sales is escalating concerns about missing feature commitments and competitive positioning. This is a priority.
metric_warnings.ceo_cooling: The CEO's enthusiasm for the product direction appears to be cooling based on recent communications.
metric_warnings.nps_silent_decline: NPS hasn't moved, but the underlying trend shows subtle erosion in customer satisfaction.

product_pulse_narratives.narrative: The product pulse is strong across all vectors. Churn is trending down, indicating customer stickiness and satisfaction. Support volume remains manageable, suggesting the product is stable and self-service options are working. Customer sentiment in outreach and NPS tracking is uniformly positive. This is the ideal state—healthy product health across all metrics. The question now is how to maintain this while introducing change without disrupting what's working.

The product pulse is neutral across all dimensions. Churn is neither improving nor declining—customers are stable but not enthusiastic about their choice. Support load is typical for the install base. Customer sentiment is muted; customers are content but not advocates. This is the norm for mature products. The challenge is figuring out whether to optimize the current state or invest in innovation to shift sentiment upward.

All product health metrics are concerning simultaneously. Churn is elevated, indicating customers are evaluating alternatives. Support load is spiking, suggesting either product instability or poor self-serve usability. Customer sentiment is negative across all channels. This is a crisis scenario that demands immediate investigation and remedy. Something fundamental has broken in either the product experience or the market perception of it. Leadership will expect urgent corrective action.

Churn is down and customer sentiment is positive, which is the core health signal we care about. Support load is neither spiking nor declining, hovering at normal levels. This suggests the product is resonating with customers, though there may be usability gaps that are driving moderate support volume. The combination is healthy. Focus on maintaining customer happiness while looking for opportunities to reduce support friction.

Support load is elevated while churn remains stable and sentiment is neutral. This suggests customers are having friction with the product but aren't yet leaving because switching costs are high or alternatives aren't compelling. Support volume is a leading indicator of churn—if we don't address the underlying issues causing support tickets, churn will likely follow. This is an early warning that needs response.

Churn is down and support efficiency is good, both positive signs. Customer sentiment, however, is muted—customers are staying but not excited. This suggests the product is stable and intuitive enough that people don't need help, but it's not driving delight or advocacy. The foundation is solid, which gives room to focus on differentiation or delightful experiences that move sentiment from neutral to positive.

Churn is elevated while support load and sentiment remain neutral. This is a danger sign suggesting that customers are evaluating exits not because of immediate friction or poor sentiment, but because they're not getting sufficient value or perceived competitive advantage. Support load and sentiment being stable means the product is adequate, but apparently not good enough to earn loyalty. Competitive pressure is likely involved.

Customer sentiment is positive despite churn being stable and support load being normal. This is the best combination for expansion: happy customers who are stable and reasonably self-sufficient. There's room to improve either retention or support efficiency, but the foundation of customer satisfaction is solid. Use this goodwill to invest in features that deepen stickiness or earn upsell opportunities.

Support efficiency is excellent while churn remains stable and sentiment is neutral. This means the product is intuitive and self-service is working well. Customers aren't leaving, but they're also not particularly enthusiastic. The low support burden gives team capacity to focus on sentiment-shifting initiatives—features or experiences that move neutral customers toward advocacy.

Both churn and support load are elevated while sentiment remains neutral. This is a double-problem: customers are leaving AND consuming significant support resources. The combination suggests product issues are driving support volume, but customers are also questioning whether the product is worth the friction. There's instability in the customer base. Immediate focus on root-cause investigation and remediation is required.

Churn is improving despite negative sentiment, which is a confusing signal. Customers are staying despite saying they're unhappy. This could indicate that switching costs are high, competitive alternatives are weak, or sentiment data is lagging behind behavior. Support load being normal suggests the product works, even if it doesn't delight. Monitor sentiment closely—negative sentiment can be a leading indicator of future churn.

Support load is elevated while customer sentiment remains positive and churn is stable. Customers are happy but need help using the product. This suggests strong demand and positive perception, but usability or self-service gaps are creating support burden. The goodwill is there—investing in better onboarding or clearer documentation could dramatically improve support efficiency while maintaining customer happiness.

Elevated churn despite positive sentiment is a notable contradiction. Customers seem satisfied when surveyed, but they're still leaving. This could indicate that happiness is high but competitive alternatives are more compelling, or that sentiment data is biased toward retained customers. Support load being normal suggests the product itself isn't broken. The problem is retention, not product quality.

Churn is improving despite elevated support load and negative sentiment—an unusual combination that suggests something has shifted positively at a market or product level despite ongoing friction. Customers are choosing to stay despite being unhappy and needing help. This window of opportunity may be temporary. Urgent focus on resolving support drivers and addressing sentiment issues is warranted before the positive churn trend reverses.

We appreciate {{player_role}}'s contributions and wish them well in finding a role that is a better fit.

quarter_opening_texts.template: Welcome to {{next_quarter}}. The year is fresh and your OKRs are ambitious. Nobody has formed strong opinions about your judgment yet, which is a temporary advantage. The board is energized, executives are optimistic, and unrealistic expectations are abundant. You have a few weeks before Q1 results begin to expose whether your planning was sound or merely hopeful. The team is ready. Your job is to be clear about scope, realistic about dependencies, and strategic about how you allocate what will inevitably become a constraint: attention.

{{next_quarter}} is here. Fresh start, new priorities, and no historical context to constrain your decisions yet. The team is energized and executives are paying attention. This quarter is about setting a foundation—not just for delivery, but for credibility. Get some wins on the board early. Over-communicate about trade-offs. Under-promise and over-deliver if you can. By the end of {{next_quarter}}, people will have formed strong opinions about your competence. Make those opinions favorable.

{{next_quarter}} begins. The year is yours to shape. Everyone is optimistic, expectations are unformed, and you have room to set the narrative. Your first quarter output will establish the baseline for what people expect from you going forward. Choose your commitments carefully. Communicate clearly. Deliver reliably. If you succeed here, you'll have built capital for future quarters when conditions are less favorable and constraints are tighter.

{{next_quarter}} arrives with the weight of {{prev_quarter}} results behind it. {{q1_review_reference}}. The honeymoon, if there was one, is over. Executives have data points now. Expectations are partially formed. The sales team has opinions. This quarter is about either building on {{prev_quarter}}'s momentum or reversing course if {{prev_quarter}} was a disappointment. Either way, you're being measured against a baseline now. There's no more clean slate.

{{next_quarter}} means there are now two quarters of data in the organization's collective memory. {{q1_review_reference}}. That context shapes expectations. People have formed opinions. The team knows whether you deliver. Leadership knows whether they can trust your estimation. This quarter is about pattern-setting: are you consistent, or are {{prev_quarter}}'s results a anomaly? Deliver again. The narrative compounds quarterly.

Into {{next_quarter}}. {{q1_review_reference}}, and that precedent matters. People remember whether you shipped last quarter. They remember if you were late. You're no longer a new PM navigating early challenges; you're an operator with a track record. Choose your commitments understanding that you're being evaluated on consistency and predictability, not just raw output. The pressure increases because the data set is larger.

{{next_quarter}} arrives with half the team on rotation and nobody focused like they were in Q1. The board wants a strong second half. You want momentum heading into year-end. Reality is that {{next_quarter}} is where plans collide with vacation schedules, summer priorities, and organizational focus drift. Be strategic about what you commit to. Protect key initiatives. The team will deliver better if you're realistic about {{next_quarter}}'s constraints. Build breathing room; you'll need it.

{{next_quarter}} is here. You're on the downslope toward year-end, and the board is making noise about strong finishes. Two quarters are behind you; two more have real data. The team is tired. Focus has frayed. Your job is to identify what's actually critical and create focus around that, not try to boil the ocean. {{next_quarter}} success isn't about ambition; it's about discipline and identifying what moves the needle.

{{next_quarter}} momentum becomes important. You're halfway through the year. Leadership is forming opinions about whether the year is trending toward success or correction. {{next_quarter}} is when you prove you can execute in non-ideal conditions—limited team bandwidth, summer distraction, competing priorities. Be selective with your commitments. Be clear with stakeholders. Build {{next_quarter}} on sustainable foundations, not heroics.

{{next_quarter}} is here. This is it—the final quarter, the one that defines the year. Year-end reviews loom. Board presentations happen here. {{hardest_quarter_or_event}} is behind you, and you now have a full picture of how you navigate pressure. {{next_quarter}} is about finishing strong. You don't need to be perfect; you need to be reliable and strategic. Choose what matters, deliver it, and let the year speak for itself.

{{next_quarter}} is the final quarter. This is where years are made or broken. Three quarters of data exist. People know whether you're a consistent operator or a one-hit wonder. The CEO is watching. The board is watching. Year-end reviews are being written. {{next_quarter}} is not the time to experiment; it's the time to deliver against a clear narrative. Choose initiatives that matter and execute them with discipline.

{{next_quarter}}. The year ends here. Every decision in {{next_quarter}} will be evaluated within the context of the full year. You have a body of work behind you. {{next_quarter}} is about either cementing it as a strong year or revealing that the trajectory was overestimated. The team is tired. The board is impatient. Stakeholders are eager for next year's strategy. Your job is to navigate {{next_quarter}} with clarity and deliver what you promised. Let the outcomes speak.

ceo_focus_shifts.text: The CEO spent an hour reviewing self-serve metrics and became convinced that PLG is the only defensible growth engine. All priorities are now filtered through the lens of activation, conversion, and virality.
After seeing competitor self-serve numbers, the CEO has decided that bottom-up adoption is the future. Enterprise sales are still important, but self-serve growth is now the primary strategic focus.
The CEO read a thread about product-led growth and is now convinced we need to double down on self-serve experience. Everything else is a distraction from the real opportunity.
Board feedback suggested that self-serve expansion is the key to reaching Series C valuation multiples. CEO has pivoted hard toward optimizing the end-to-end PLG motion.
Recent self-serve cohort data looked promising and the CEO is now convinced this is where the leverage is. Enterprise will always be there, but self-serve is the growth unlock.
The CEO just got off a call with a Fortune 500 prospect and is now laser-focused on enterprise readiness. Self-serve is fine, but big deals are what matters for the next funding round.
Sales presented a pipeline forecast showing enterprise could triple revenue in 18 months. CEO has shifted all attention to making the product enterprise-ready and closing seven-figure deals.
After reviewing ARR breakdown, the CEO realized enterprise contracts drive 80% of revenue. The new priority is enterprise features, compliance, and anything that closes six-figure deals.
A competitor just announced a massive enterprise partnership and the CEO is convinced we're losing the upmarket battle. All focus is now on enterprise go-to-market and product capabilities.
The CEO met with three enterprise customers last week and came back energized about moving upmarket. Self-serve is table stakes, but enterprise is where we need to differentiate.
A production incident during a demo call convinced the CEO that tech debt is no longer negotiable. All new feature work is paused until infrastructure and reliability are addressed.
The CTO presented infrastructure cost projections that alarmed the CEO. Tech debt reduction is now the top priority to avoid compounding technical and financial problems.
After three escalations from enterprise customers about performance issues, the CEO has declared that product velocity means nothing if the product doesn't work. Tech debt is now priority zero.
The CEO read an article about technical bankruptcy and became convinced we're heading there. Strategic focus has shifted entirely to paying down tech debt before it compounds further.
Board member asked pointed questions about engineering efficiency and system reliability. CEO is now focused on tech debt reduction to demonstrate operational maturity.
After reviewing quarterly metrics, the CEO has decided to change strategic direction. New priorities are in effect immediately.
The CEO returned from the board meeting with a new perspective on what matters. Strategic focus has shifted based on investor feedback.
Market dynamics have changed and the CEO is adjusting strategy accordingly. New priorities will drive the next quarter of execution.
